title: Seven Billion Reasons for Facebook to Abandon its Face Recognition Plans
content:
The New York Times reported that Meta is considering adding face recognition technology to its smart glasses. According to an internal Meta document, the company may launch the product ‚Äúduring a dynamic political environment where many civil society groups that we would expect to attack us would have their resources focused on other concerns.‚Äù 

This is a bad idea that Meta sh
creator: Mario Trujillo

title: Discord Voluntarily Pushes Mandatory Age Verification Despite Recent Data Breach
content:
Discord has begun rolling out mandatory age verification and the internet is, understandably, freaking out.

At EFF, we‚Äôve been raising the alarm about age verification mandates for years. In December, we launched our Age Verification Resource Hub to push back against laws and platform policies that require users to hand over sensitive personal information just to acc
creator: Rindala Alajaji

title: üó£ Homeland Security Wants Names | EFFector 38.3
content:
Criticize the government online? The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) might ask Google to cough up your name. By abusing an investigative tool called "administrative subpoenas," DHS has been demanding that tech companies hand over users' names, locations, and more. We're explaining how companies can stand up for users‚Äîand covering the latest news in the fight for privacy and free speech online‚Äîwith our EFFector newsletter.

For over 35 years, EFFector has been your guide
creator: Christian Romero

title: ‚ÄúFree‚Äù Surveillance Tech Still Comes at a High and Dangerous Cost
content:
Surveillance technology vendors, federal agencies, and wealthy private donors have long helped provide local law enforcement ‚Äúfree‚Äù access to surveillance equipment that bypasses local oversight. The result is predictable: serious accountability gaps and data pipelines to other entities, including Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), that expose millions of people to harm.

The cost of ‚Äúfree‚Äù surveillance tools ‚Äî like
creator: Beryl Lipton

title: Open Letter to Tech Companies: Protect Your Users From Lawless DHS Subpoenas
content:
We are calling on technology companies like Meta and Google to stand up for their users by resisting the Department of Homeland Security's (DHS) lawless administrative subpoenas for user data. 

In the past year, DHS has consistently targeted people engaged in First Amendment activity. Among other things, the agency has issued subpoenas to technology companies to unmask or locate people who have documented ICE's activities in their community, criticized the government, or attended protests.
creator: Mario Trujillo

title: No One, Including Our Furry Friends, Will Be Safer in Ring's Surveillance Nightmare
content:
Amazon Ring‚Äôs Super Bowl ad offered a vision of our streets that should leave every person unsettled about the company‚Äôs goals for disintegrating our privacy in public.

In the ad, disguised as a heartfelt effort to reunite the lost dogs of the country with their innocent owners, the company previewed future surveillance of our streets: a world where biometric identification could be unleashed from consumer devices to identify, track, and locate anything ‚Äî human, pet, and otherwise.

The ad for Ring‚Äôs ‚ÄúSearch Party‚Äù feature highlighted the doorbell camera‚Äôs ability to scan footage across Ring devices i
creator: Beryl Lipton

title: Coalition Urges California to Revoke Permits for Federal License Plate Reader Surveillance
content:
Group led by EFF and Imperial Valley Equity & Justice Asks Gov. Newsom and Caltrans Director to Act Immediately

SAN FRANCISCO ‚Äì California must revoke permits allowing federal agencies such as Customs and Border Patrol (CBP) and the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) to put automated license plate readers along border highways, a coalition led by the Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) and
creator: Josh Richman

title: Speaking Freely: Yazan Badran
content:
Interviewer: Jillian York

Yazan Badran is an assistant professor in international media and communication studies at the Vrije Universiteit Brussel, and a researcher at the Echo research group. His research focuses on the intersection between media, journalism and politics particularly in the MENA region and within its exilic and diasporic communities.

*This interview has been edited for length and clarity. 

Jillian York: What does free speech or fr
creator: Jillian C. York
